{{Infobox language |name=Ume Sami |nativename=Ubmejensámien giella |states=[[Norway]], [[Sweden]] |speakers=20 |date=2000 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Uralic |fam2=[[Sami languages|Sami]] |fam3=[[Western Sami languages|Western]] |iso3=sju |glotto=umes1235 |glottorefname=Ume Sami |script=[[Latin script|Latin]] |map=Sami languages large.png |mapcaption=Ume Sami is '''2''' on this map. }} '''Ume Sami''' is a [[Sami languages|Sami language]] spoken in [[Sweden]] and (formerly) in [[Norway]]. It is a [[Endangered language|moribund language]] with only about 10 native speakers left which used to be spoken mainly along the [[Ume River]] in the south of present-day [[Arjeplog Municipality|Arjeplog]], in [[Sorsele Municipality|Sorsele]] and [[Arvidsjaur Municipality|Arvidsjaur]].{{cite web |first=Olavi |last=Korhonen |work=The Saami: a cultural encyclopaedia |title=Ume Saami language |location=Helsinki |year=2005 |pages=421–422 |url=http://www-db.helsinki.fi/cgi-bin/thw/?${APPL}=saamien&${BASE}=saamien&${THWIDS}=22.0/1341400440_5538&${MAXHITS}=5000&${HTML}=docu2&${THWURLSAVE}=0/1341400440_5538&${TRIPSHOW}=form=biblen |accessdate= }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}Pekka Sammallahti, ''The Saami languages: an introduction'', Kárášjohka, 1998 ==Phonology== ===Consonants=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" ! colspan="2" | ![[Labial consonant|Labial]] ![[Dental consonant|Dental]]/
[[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ![[Postalveolar consonant|Post-
alveolar]] ![[Velar consonant|Velar]] ![[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Stop consonant|Plosive]] | {{IPA|/p/}} | {{IPA|/t/}} | | {{IPA|/k/}} | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Affricate consonant|Affricate]] | | {{IPA|/t͡s/}} | {{IPA|/t͡ʃ/}} | | |- ! rowspan="2" |[[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] ![[Voicelessness|voiceless]] | | {{IPA|/s/}} | {{IPA|/ʃ/}} | | {{IPA|/h/}} |- ![[Voice (phonetics)|voiced]] | {{IPA|/v/}} | {{IPA|/ð/}} | | | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | {{IPA|/m/}} | {{IPA|/n/}} | {{IPA|/ɲ/}} | {{IPA|/ŋ/}} | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Rhotic consonant|Trill]] | | {{IPA|/r/}} | | | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | | {{IPA|/l/}} | {{IPA|/j/}} | | |} An {{IPA|/f, ʋ/}} and {{IPA|/θ/}} are allophones of {{IPA|/v/}} and {{IPA|/ð/}}. When a {{IPA|/h/}} sound occurs before a plosive or an affricate sound, they are then realized as preaspirated sounds. If an {{IPA|/l/}} sound occurs before a {{IPA|/j/}} sound, it is realized as a palatal lateral {{IPA|/ʎ/}} sound. It is said that some western dialects of the language do not have a presence of the {{IPA|/ð/}} phoneme. ===Vowels=== {| | {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+ Short vowels |- ! ! colspan="2" | Front ! Central ! Back |- ! Close | {{IPA|/i/}} | {{IPA|/y/}} | {{IPA|/ʉ/}} | {{IPA|/u/}} |- ! Mid | colspan="2" | {{IPA|/e/}} | | {{IPA|/o/}} |- ! Open | colspan="2" | | {{IPA|/a/}} | |} | {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+ Long vowels |- ! ! Front ! Central ! Back |- ! Close | {{IPA|/iː/}} | {{IPA|/ʉː/}} | {{IPA|/uː/}} |- ! Mid | {{IPA|/eː/}} | | {{IPA|/oː/}} |- ! Open | | {{IPA|/aː/}} | |} |} Four diphthongs are included; {{IPA|/ie/}}, {{IPA|/yʉ/}}, {{IPA|/ʉi/}}, {{IPA|/uo/}}. A schwa sound {{IPA|/ə/}} may exist as an allophone of various vowel sounds.{{Cite book|title=Huvuddrag i umesamisk grammatik|last=von Gertten|first=Daniel|publisher=University of Oslo|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=}} ==Writing system== Until 2010, Ume Sami did not have an official written standard, although it was the first Sami language to be written extensively (because [[Sámi school (Sweden)#History|a private christian school]] for Sami children started in [[Lycksele]] 1632, where Ume Sami was spoken). The [[New Testament]] was published in Ume Sami in 1755 and the first Bible in Sami was also published in Ume Sami, in 1811. The current official orthography is maintained by the ''Working group for Ume Sami'', whose most recent recommendation was published in 2016. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! Letter ! Phoneme(s) |- | [[A]] a | {{IPA|/ʌ/}} |- | [[Á]] á | {{IPA|/ɑː/}} |- | [[B]] b | {{IPA|/p/}} |- | [[D]] d | {{IPA|/t/}} |- | [[Đ]] đ | {{IPA|/ð/}} |- | [[E]] e | {{IPA|/e/}}, {{IPA|/eː/}} |- | [[F]] f | {{IPA|/f/}} |- | [[G]] g | {{IPA|/k/}} |- | [[H]] h | {{IPA|/h/}} |- | [[I]] i | {{IPA|/i/}} |- | [[Ï]] ï | {{IPA|/ɨ/}} |- | [[J]] j | {{IPA|/j/}} |- | [[K]] k | {{IPA|/hk/}}, {{IPA|/k/}} |- | [[L]] l | {{IPA|/l/}} |- | [[M]] m | {{IPA|/m/}} |- | [[N]] n | {{IPA|/n/}} |- | [[Ŋ]] ŋ | {{IPA|/ŋ/}} |- | [[O]] o | {{IPA|/o/}} (only in diphthongs) |- | [[P]] p | {{IPA|/hp/}}, {{IPA|/p/}} |- | [[R]] r | {{IPA|/r/}} |- | [[S]] s | {{IPA|/s/}} |- | [[T]] t | {{IPA|/ht/}}, {{IPA|/t/}} |- | [[Ŧ]] ŧ | {{IPA|/θ/}} |- | [[U]] u | {{IPA|/u/}}, {{IPA|/uː/}} |- | [[Ü]] ü | {{IPA|/ʉ/}}, {{IPA|/ʉː/}} |- | [[V]] v | {{IPA|/v/}} |- | [[Y]] y | {{IPA|/y/}} |- | [[Å]] å | {{IPA|/o/}}, {{IPA|/ɔː/}} |- | [[Ä]] ä | {{IPA|/ɛː/}} |- | [[Ö]] ö | {{IPA|/œ/}} (only in diphthongs) |} Shortcomings: * Vowel length is ambiguous for the letters {{angbr|u}}, {{angbr|ü}} and {{angbr|å}}. In reference works, the length is indicated by a macron ({{angbr|ū}}, {{angbr|ǖ}}, {{angbr|å̄}}). In older orthographies, length could be indicated by writing a double vowel. * No distinction is made between long and overlong consonants, both are written with a double consonant letter. In reference works, the overlong stops are indicated with a vertical line ({{angbr|bˈb}}, {{angbr|dˈd}} etc.). ==Grammar== === Consonant gradation === Unlike its southern neighbor [[Southern Sami]], Ume Sami has [[consonant gradation]]. However, gradation is more limited than it is in the more northern Sami languages, because it does not occur in the case of short vowels followed by a consonant that can gradate to quantity 1 (that is, Proto-Samic single consonants or geminates). In these cases, only quantity 3 appears. Consonant clusters can gradate regardless of the preceding vowel. === Cases === ===Pronouns=== ===Verbs=== ====Person and grammatical number==== The verbs in Ume Sami have three persons: * first person * second person * third person There are three grammatical numbers: singular, dual and plural. ====Mood ==== Ume Sami has two [[grammatical mood]]s: *[[Grammatical mood#Indicative|indicative]] *[[Imperative mood|imperative]] ====Tense==== ====Negative verb==== Ume Sami, like Finnish, the other Sami languages and Estonian, has a [[negative verb]]. In Ume Sami, the negative verb conjugates according to [[Grammatical mood|mood]] (indicative and imperative), [[Grammatical person|person]] (1st, 2nd and 3rd) and [[Grammatical number|number]] (singular, dual and plural). ==Example== {| |----- | '''Transcription''' || '''Swedish Translation'''||'''English Translation''' |----- | Båtsuoj-bieŋjuv galggá báddie-gietjiesna álggiet lieratit. De tjuavrrá jiehtja viegadit ráddiesta ráddáje jah nav ájaj livva-sijiesna, guh jiehtják súhph. Die galggá daina báddie-bieŋjijne viegadit bijrra ieluon, nav júhtie biegŋja galggá vuöjdniet gúktie almatjh gelggh dahkat. Lierruo-biegŋja daggár bälij vánatallá ieluon bijrra ja ij akttak bijgŋuolissa luöjtieh. Die måddie bálliena daggár biegŋja, juhka ij leäh ållást lieratuvvama, die butsijda válldá ja dulvada. De daggár bälij tjuavrrá suv báddáje válldiet jah slåvvat. | Renhunden ska man börja lära i koppel. Då måste man själv springa från den ena kanten till den andra (av renhjorden) och så också på (renarnas) viloplats, medan de andra äter. Då ska man med den där bandhunden springa runt hjorden, så att hunden ser, hur folket gör. Lärohunden springer en sådan gång runt hjorden och låter ingen undslippa. Så finns det ofta sådana hundar, som inte har lärt sig helt, som tar någon ren och jagar iväg den. Då måste man en sådan gång sätta band på den och slå den. | A reindeer [[herding dog]] must begin its training with a leash. Then one has to run from one side [of the herd] to the other and also on the area where they [the reindeer] rest, while others are eating. One must run around the herd with the dog [to be trained] on a leash, so that the dog sees how people do it. The trained dog then runs around the herd and does not allow any to slip away. Then there are often dogs that are not fully trained [and] who single out a reindeer and drive it away [i.e. to kill it]. Then one must put a leash on that [dog] and strike it. |} ==See also== *[[Sami people]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Ume Sami language}} * [http://www.kirjasto.oulu.fi/saamilottit/ Sámi lottit] Names of birds found in [[Sápmi (area)|Sápmi]] in a number of languages, including Skolt Sami and English.
